item.title: About
item.description: This site showcases projects where Brandon worked out something he thought was worth remarking on, hopefully to the benemusment of others. In his free time indoors, Brandon wonders if he's actually fooling anyone by referring to himself in the third person. Outdoors, he enjoys solo backpacking, camping, hiking, long distance trail running, bicycling, snowshoeing, and shooting cool shots with his camera. Back indoors, he revels in R programming, applied statistics, exploring open source technologies, writing creative non-fiction (think The New Yorker, but not as good) and short stories (think David Foster Wallace or Saunders, but not as good), and driving his Tesla through the dank mountains of the Pacific Northwest (think fast, but faster).

item.title: Bias in the Machine?
item.description: Goals of this post Plot Data Science books over time to show rise in data science tech and conversations. - visualize covers of books somehow. - https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSECommerceService/latest/DG/becomingDev.html - https://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSECommerceService/latest/DG/becomingAssociate.html - Conclude something about the use of this predicting recidivism to inform sentencing/type of rehabilitation and explain. - https://stackoverflow.com/questions/8251632/amazon-product-api-with-r Intro I'm over two years late to the party. In the Spring of 2016 Pro Publica wrote an article titled “Machine Bias”, the gist of which is in its subtitle: “Thereâ€™s software used across the country to predict future criminals.

item.title: To Explain or to Predict?
item.description: “To Explain or to Predict?" Statistical modeling is a powerful tool for developing and testing theories by way of causal explanation, prediction, and description. In many disciplines there is near-exclusive use of statistical modeling for causal explanation and the assumption that models with high explanatory power are inherently of high predictive power. Conflation between explanation and prediction is common, yet the distinction must be understood for progressing scientific knowledge. While this distinction has been recognized in the philosophy of science, the statistical literature lacks a thorough discussion of the many differences that arise in the process of modeling for an explanatory versus a predictive goal.

item.title: I Web Therefore I Am
item.description: Yihui Xie (Yee-how Nee) wrote the R package blogdown to create static websites – like this one – using a bifecta of technologies: Hugo and R Markdown. I'm really impressed. It's super fast, responsive, and has a growing community of developers to bring cool themes into the digital universe. Plus it'll give me the computational flexibility I'm after to showcase analyses that live in R Markdown. Because this is my first post, I've got to dedicate it to Yihui.

item.title: Contact
item.description: Contact me when you wish to contact me.

item.title: What do you do, like actually?
item.description: It's rare if I'm completely certain of something, but I know I do an insufficient job of describing what I do for a living becuase the same members of family and friend groups ask me the same question almost every time we meet: The disconnect is threefold: 1. “Data science” sounds super boring; 2. “Data science” sounds made up; 3. “Data Scientist” doesn't tell you much about what's actually done on the job like other job titles, which give away what they're about right there in the title, e.
